faculty.name: Pamela Bjorkman
faculty.requirements: Enthusiasm for doing experiments
faculty.opportunities: See https://www.its.caltech.edu/~bjorker/

faculty.name: Tsui-Fen Chou
faculty.opportunities: please contact me directly

faculty.name: David M. Glover
faculty.requirements: motivation and enthusuasm
faculty.opportunities: We study the molecular cell biology of the centriole - in centrosomes in cell division; in the basal bodies of cilia; and in their interaction with membraneous organelles.  We use Drosophila and mouse as models and the work has impoications for both cell biology and all stages of development

faculty.name: Elizabeth Hong
faculty.requirements: Undergraduate research students must be highly motivated, demonstrate good time management, and exhibit strong intellectual curiosity. Must be willing and excited to read primary literature. Experience with coding, data science, electronics, and/or small device design/fabrication is a plus.
faculty.students: Matt Bauer, Sharne Sun, Brian Nguyen, Katelyn Lee
faculty.opportunities: The Hong lab studies the neural basis of chemical sensing in the fruit fly Drosophila. Research projects are available in the analytical chemistry of natural odor sources, quantitative analysis of insect behavior, molecular cloning and insect genome engineering, electroantennography recordings, analysis of functional imaging datasets, or computational modeling of olfactory circuit structure and function. A minimum commitment of 10 hrs/week is required for undergraduate researchers. Caltech students must commit to academic year research if seeking a summer position in the lab. Interested students should submit a cover letter to ejhong@caltech.edu describing why they are interested in research in the lab.

faculty.name: Pamela Bjorkman
faculty.requirements: Enthusiasm for doing experiments
faculty.opportunities: See https://www.its.caltech.edu/~bjorker/

faculty.name: David Prober
faculty.requirements: Students who are a good fit for the lab are hard-working, highly motivated, and rigorous in performing experimental and computational tasks. Introductory molecular biology, cell biology, and neuroscience coursework is preferred but not required.
faculty.opportunities: Several projects are available for motivated and rigorous undergraduate students. Experimental projects involve using zebrafish genetics and imaging to understand mechanisms that regulate sleep. Computational projects involve analysis of zebrafish whole-brain (100,000 neurons) neuronal activity imaging datasets to identify neuronal mechanisms that underlie sleep and to test models for sleep regulation.

faculty.name: Elizabeth Hong
faculty.requirements: Undergraduate research students must be highly motivated, demonstrate good time management, and exhibit strong intellectual curiosity. Must be willing and excited to read primary literature. Experience with coding, data science, electronics, and/or small device design/fabrication is a plus.
faculty.students: Matt Bauer, Sharne Sun, Brian Nguyen, Katelyn Lee
faculty.opportunities: The Hong lab studies the neural basis of chemical sensing in the fruit fly Drosophila. Research projects are available in the analytical chemistry of natural odor sources, quantitative analysis of insect behavior, molecular cloning and insect genome engineering, electroantennography recordings, analysis of functional imaging datasets, or computational modeling of olfactory circuit structure and function. A minimum commitment of 10 hrs/week is required for undergraduate researchers. Caltech students must commit to academic year research if seeking a summer position in the lab. Interested students should submit a cover letter to ejhong@caltech.edu describing why they are interested in research in the lab.

faculty.name: David Prober
faculty.requirements: Students who are a good fit for the lab are hard-working, highly motivated, and rigorous in performing experimental and computational tasks. Introductory molecular biology, cell biology, and neuroscience coursework is preferred but not required.
faculty.opportunities: Several projects are available for motivated and rigorous undergraduate students. Experimental projects involve using zebrafish genetics and imaging to understand mechanisms that regulate sleep. Computational projects involve analysis of zebrafish whole-brain (100,000 neurons) neuronal activity imaging datasets to identify neuronal mechanisms that underlie sleep and to test models for sleep regulation.

faculty.name: David M. Glover
faculty.requirements: motivation and enthusuasm
faculty.opportunities: We study the molecular cell biology of the centriole - in centrosomes in cell division; in the basal bodies of cilia; and in their interaction with membraneous organelles.  We use Drosophila and mouse as models and the work has impoications for both cell biology and all stages of development

faculty.name: Angela Stathopoulos
faculty.requirements: Interest in Developmental Biology; Willingness to learn; Commitment of at least 1 academic year and 6 hrs/week
faculty.opportunities: A position is available for an undergraduate researcher to work on the first epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT) that occurs in Drosophila embryos associated with mesoderm migration at gastrulation. The project involves studying the role of ~10 genes isolated from single cell RNA-seq studies to identify novel regulators of EMT. RNAi and Crispr gene mutants (generated by the research team) will be investigated using in situ hybridization and live imaging. This researcher will receive training from postdoc Jingjing Sun.

faculty.name: Angela Stathopoulos
faculty.requirements: Interest in Developmental Biology, specifically in the regulation of gene expression
faculty.opportunities: Work together with postdoc Susan Newcomb to devise a novel live imaging approach for studying chromatin dynamics in the Drosophila embryo. The undergraduate researcher will be expected to commit 6 hr/week for one academic year. Their duties will include learning/applying various molecular biology techniques as well as capturing movies of developing embryos on the confocal microscope.

faculty.name: Elizabeth Hong
faculty.requirements: Undergraduate research students must be highly motivated, demonstrate good time management, and exhibit strong intellectual curiosity. Must be willing and excited to read primary literature. Experience with coding, data science, electronics, and/or small device design/fabrication is a plus.

faculty.name: Andre Hoelz
faculty.requirements: enthusiasm, dedication
faculty.students: Anna Mortari, Tao Zhang, Asha Rollins, Tiba Hamza
faculty.opportunities: students work with a graduate student or postdoc in the group, learn systematically molecular biology, biochemistry, structural biology and cell biology techniques.

faculty.name: Lu Wei
faculty.requirements: Strong interests in our research. That is better than anything else.
faculty.opportunities: Work with a graduate mentor. Follow their research and learn wet-lab skills. I hope you will be able to in charge of part of the research once you are comfortable to do so.

faculty.name: Shu-ou Shan
faculty.requirements: Some previous research experience; have done the homework to read some of the group's publications.
faculty.opportunities: Molecular biology (cloning), protein expression and purification, basic protein characterizations.

faculty.name: Andre Hoelz
faculty.requirements: enthusiasm, dedication
faculty.students: Anna Mortari, Tao Zhang, Asha Rollins, Tiba Hamza
faculty.opportunities: students work with a graduate student or postdoc in the group, learn systematically molecular biology, biochemistry, structural biology and cell biology techniques.

faculty.name: Lu Wei
faculty.requirements: Strong interests in our research. That is better than anything else.
faculty.opportunities: Work with a graduate mentor. Follow their research and learn wet-lab skills. I hope you will be able to in charge of part of the research once you are comfortable to do so.

faculty.name: Steven Low
faculty.requirements: Knowledge of circuit analysis, good software and simulation experience, enthusiastic about clean energy & smart grid, independent and reliable
faculty.opportunities: Working with utility company (e.g. Pasadena Water and Power) to apply new technologies  to help integrate solar power at scale into their electricity distribution grid.

faculty.name: Anima Anandkumar
faculty.requirements: Preferably ML courses

faculty.name: Gregg Hallinan
faculty.requirements: A strong software skill set is essential (one of python, julia, C). Understanding of the Fourier transform is strongly desired! If you have taken an Astro course that's a welcome bonus.
faculty.opportunities: The student will be mentored by the advisor and a postdoc on the creation of maps of the radio sky using a new radio telescope called the OVRO-LWA - the technique used is described here - https://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.3847/1538-3881/aac721
faculty.website: currently being redesigned and is off-line

faculty.name: Steven Low
faculty.requirements: Knowledge of circuit analysis, good software and simulation experience, enthusiastic about clean energy & smart grid, independent and reliable
faculty.opportunities: Working with utility company (e.g. Pasadena Water and Power) to apply new technologies  to help integrate solar power at scale into their electricity distribution grid.

faculty.name: Guillaume Blanquart
faculty.requirements: No requirement necessary.  I will work with you to design a project that fits your expertise(s).
faculty.students: Jules Penot, Perry Samimy, Joaquin Gomez, Rithvik Musuku
faculty.opportunities: Fluid mechanics, thermodynamics, combustion, aerospace

faculty.name: Joe Kirschvink
faculty.requirements: Brilliance
faculty.students: Noah Moran, Michael Batchev, Alexandra Klipfel
faculty.opportunities: Interactions of electromagnetic fields on life

faculty.name: Bethany Ehlmann
faculty.requirements: interest in planetary surface science topics; knowledge of scripting/coding or geology is a plus
faculty.opportunities: We have a variety of projects on the composition of planetary surfaces. In-lab measurements of spectra of planetary materials; remote sensing analysis of data from Mars, the Moon, and asteroids; modeling of detection thresholds for minerals on Mars and the Moon with Raman and IR spectroscopy; scientific coding to make programs for image analysis and image viewing (i.e., CS for science!).

faculty.name: Joe Kirschvink
faculty.requirements: Brilliance
faculty.students: Noah Moran, Michael Batchev, Alexandra Klipfel
faculty.opportunities: Interactions of electromagnetic fields on life

In-lab measurements of spectra of planetary materials; remote sensing analysis of data from Mars, the Moon, and asteroids; modeling of detection thresholds for minerals on Mars and the Moon with Raman and IR spectroscopy; scientific coding to make programs for image analysis and image viewing (i.e., CS for science!).

faculty.name: Kota Saito
faculty.requirements: mathematical ability,  computer programming (python)
faculty.opportunities: Develop a model of consumer's decision making /Application of machine learning, psychology, and ecnonomics to predict consumer choice

faculty.name: Sunil Golwala
faculty.requirements: python programming experience, modest CS coursework (an understand of how programs should be structured)
faculty.opportunities:
Two projects are available:
1) Running public code to calculate dark matter interaction cross-sections at lower energies than have been explored previously.  This may require learning matlab to make the results of the public code accessible to an existing matlab code base.
2) Analytic calculations and simply python simulations of estimation and removal of the cosmic microwave background from images of galaxy clusters at millimeter wavelengths.

faculty.name: Nick Hutzler
faculty.requirements: Opportunities available at all levels
faculty.students: SURF 2021: Kat Gorou, Adrian Lopez, Gavin McCabe, Emily Pan, Victoria Su
faculty.opportunities: A rather wide variety, both experimental and theoretical.

faculty.name: Sergei Gukov
faculty.requirements: algebraic topology and quantum field theory

faculty.name: Manuel Endres
faculty.opportunities: Please contact me for details.

faculty.name: Sergei Gukov
faculty.requirements: algebraic topology and quantum field theory

faculty.name: Bjarne Schuelke
faculty.requirements: They should have sucessfully completed the basic mathematics courses and at least one course in combinatorics (like Math 6 or Math 121)
faculty.opportunities: Read, present, and discuss research papers and work on open problems.

faculty.name: Matthew Graham
faculty.requirements: Competency in Python programming
faculty.opportunities: The Zwicky Transient Facility (ZTF) has over two billion astronomical time series associated with it and we are interested in finding and studying rare and unusual objects in this collection.

faculty.name: Mansi M. Kasliwal
faculty.requirements: Fluency in Python
faculty.students: Xander Hall, Derek Ing, Kayton Trung

faculty.opportunities:

2) Analytic calculations and simply python simulations of estimation and removal of the cosmic microwave background from images of galaxy clusters at millimeter wavelengths.

faculty.name: George Djorgovski
faculty.requirements: Mostly programming skills
faculty.opportunities: It depends on the project.  A lot of it involves Augmented/Virtual Reality, software architectures, and some Machine Learning.

faculty.opportunities:
Two projects are available:
1) Running public code to calculate dark matter interaction cross-sections at lower energies than have been explored previously.  This may require learning matlab to make the results of the public code accessible to an existing matlab code base.
2) Analytic calculations and simply python simulations of estimation and removal of the cosmic microwave background from images of galaxy clusters at millimeter wavelengths.

faculty.name: George Djorgovski
faculty.requirements: Mostly programming skills
faculty.opportunities: It depends on the project.  A lot of it involves Augmented/Virtual Reality, software architectures, and some Machine Learning.
